title: 111_hr5913
content:
The "Text a Tip Act of 2010" establishes a pilot program for texting crime tips. The Attorney General may grant funds to law enforcement agencies for an anonymous tip program using cell phone text messaging. The funds can be used for operating expenses, promotion, and the Federal share should not exceed 75 percent of the program cost. Grant amounts should supplement non-Federal funds, not replace them. The program requirements for the anonymous tip program using cell phone text messaging include grant funds from the Attorney General for operating expenses and promotion. The Federal share should not exceed 75 percent of the program cost, and grant amounts should supplement non-Federal funds. A texting tip program of a State or local law enforcement agency eligible for a grant under this Act must comply with requirements such as administering the program, stripping incoming text messages of identifying information, ensuring texts are untraceable, not replacing existing hotlines, training personnel to respond to tips, making the program compatible with mobile phone providers, and including an unidentifiable code for follow-up information. The texting program for law enforcement agencies should include an unidentifiable code for tipsters to provide follow-up information, a feature to abort tips, no additional fees on tipsters' mobile phones, and promotion to encourage citizen participation, especially among youth. SEC. 4. APPLICATIONS.

To request a grant under this Act, a State or local law enforcement agency must submit an application to the Attorney General containing required information.

SEC. 5. REPORTS AND EVALUATIONS.

Recipients of grants must submit yearly reports on activities' effectiveness, and the Attorney General will report to the Senate and House Committees on Judiciary. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS.

The term "texting tip program" allows citizens to anonymously text tips to law enforcement agencies to aid in criminal justice by stripping texts of identifying information. "Texting" refers to sending written messages from a mobile phone.

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2016 for the Attorney General to carry out this Act.
